content.raw:
I believe Carlos just merged PR 107, so there are some conflicts.  Conceptually, the main difference is that now the water height changes with time, which is calculated in the current default something like…

```
double waveHeight = WavefieldSampler::ComputeDepthSimply(
       *waveParams, linkFrame.Pos(), simTime);
```

I was able to run the first demo `roslaunch usv_gazebo_plugins buoyancy_plugin_demo.launch`.

I should be able to review tomorrow.  Let me know if you need help resolving the conflicts.

content.raw:
Yes - the wave\_model parameter is required.  Sorry about that.

I added a very small [PR 123](#!/osrf/vrx/pull-requests/123/connecting-wave-model-to-buoyancy-plugin/diff) with a working demo world.  Take a look at the results with a non-zero wave state - the motion seems out of sync.  For reasonable wave parameter settings see [#!/osrf/vrx/wiki/documentation/wavefield\_envelope](#!/osrf/vrx/wiki/documentation/wavefield_envelope)

content.raw: What led you to needing the `noexcept` here?
content.html: What led you to needing the noexcept here?

content.raw: My understanding is that with STL libraries move constructors cannot throw exceptions since they have no way of recovering half way through a move. Noexcept makes a hard guarantee that the move constructor does not through any exceptions.
content.html: My understanding is that with STL libraries move constructors cannot throw exceptions since they have no way of recovering half way through a move. Noexcept makes a hard guarantee that the move constructor does not through any exceptions.

content.raw: Makes sense now that I see you are using the move sematics below.
content.html: Makes sense now that I see you are using the move sematics below.

content.raw:
This may be more personal preference, but I’m not a fan of using a type alias here.  I prefer the added verbosity of including the full type name in the code.  I do see the other side that it simplifies the code, but to me the added reference in the header file has the potential to add confusion.

@{557058:4ded1ddf-947e-4154-bbd1-3dba24f1bdbd} might have better guidance on any Gazebo conventions here.
content.html:
This may be more personal preference, but I’m not a fan of using a type alias here. I prefer the added verbosity of including the full type name in the code. I do see the other side that it simplifies the code, but to me the added reference in the header file has the potential to add confusion.

@Carlos Agüero might have better guidance on any Gazebo conventions here.

content.raw: We typically avoid aliases unless it’s a super verbose custom type.
content.html: We typically avoid aliases unless it’s a super verbose custom type.

content.raw: The reason I used it was because it was making function defs very long, especially ones that use 3-4 Vector3’s. Should I refactor this?
content.html: The reason I used it was because it was making function defs very long, especially ones that use 3-4 Vector3’s. Should I refactor this?

content.raw: That would be my preference.  I think it will avoid confusion in maintenance, even if the function definitions are a few lines.
content.html: That would be my preference. I think it will avoid confusion in maintenance, even if the function definitions are a few lines.

content.html: The idea here was if someone used the Base ShapeType it would return None for the shape type

content.raw:
Is there an easy way to explain this interpretation of drag force?  I don’t have the Catto reference you mention.

* I can see that utility in having the force be modulated by the ratio of submerged/total volume, but why would total mass of the object matter?   Perhaps as a way to limit the consequential acceleration?
* It appears you are using a fixed total mass of 2 kg?
content.html:
Is there an easy way to explain this interpretation of drag force? I don’t have the Catto reference you mention.

  • I can see that utility in having the force be modulated by the ratio of submerged/total volume, but why would total mass of the object matter? Perhaps as a way to limit the consequential acceleration?
  • It appears you are using a fixed total mass of 2 kg?

content.raw: The 2 is a bug. I will fix that
content.html: The 2 is a bug. I will fix that

content.raw: I was able to find the full reference.  I believe the mass is being included in the ad-hoc drag model so that the drag coefficient is more a way of specifying a drag acceleration \(rather than a drag force\).  Seems like a reasonable approach.
content.html: I was able to find the full reference. I believe the mass is being included in the ad-hoc drag model so that the drag coefficient is more a way of specifying a drag acceleration (rather than a drag force). Seems like a reasonable approach.

content.raw: Why square the characteristic length?
content.html: Why square the characteristic length?

content.raw: I was able to dig up the reference you are using for this.  It appears to be an ad-hoc relationship.
content.html: I was able to dig up the reference you are using for this. It appears to be an ad-hoc relationship.

content.raw: I cant figure out why this is squared
content.html: I cant figure out why this is squared

content.raw: The reference is brief, but I think it is just a convention for the units.  They specify the coefficient in units of \[1/s\] so you need L^2 to get the expression to be in units of torque \[Nm\].  I think we are find justifying it with the reference.
content.html: The reference is brief, but I think it is just a convention for the units. They specify the coefficient in units of [1/s] so you need L^2 to get the expression to be in units of torque [Nm]. I think we are find justifying it with the reference.

content.raw:
I have a demo that I was using to test the buoy response - both from the Gazebo view and in the camera views.

```
roslaunch wave_gazebo wave_wamv.launch 
```

I think this would be a valuable demo to use for evaluation.  Currently there are some problems in getting this demo to run.

* polyform\_a? models don’t have the updated buoyancy plugin params.
* It looks like the surmark950410 model is missing a <wave\_model> tag.

    * Also, in experimenting with this, it appears that when a model is missing the <wave\_model> tag it causes Gazebo to seg fault.
    
* Visually looks like the buoys \(surmark\*\) are not floating at the proper location.

Please try this out this demo with a few different sea states \(low, medium and high\) to see how things work.  Would recommend settings \(see [ocean\_waves](#!/osrf/vrx/src/281853f0e0b76b27e399e039e958bd9517df1a28/wave_gazebo/world_models/ocean_waves/model.sdf.erb?at=issue%2394-buoyancy) model\) something like…

1. Low \(flat\): period = 5, gain = 0
2. Medium: period = 5, gain = 1
3. High: period = 10, gain = 1
content.html:
I have a demo that I was using to test the buoy response - both from the Gazebo view and in the camera views.

roslaunch wave_gazebo wave_wamv.launch

I think this would be a valuable demo to use for evaluation. Currently there are some problems in getting this demo to run.

  • polyform_a? models don’t have the updated buoyancy plugin params.

  • It looks like the surmark950410 model is missing a <wave_model> tag.

    • Also, in experimenting with this, it appears that when a model is missing the <wave_model> tag it causes Gazebo to seg fault.

  • Visually looks like the buoys (surmark*) are not floating at the proper location.

Please try this out this demo with a few different sea states (low, medium and high) to see how things work. Would recommend settings (see ocean_waves model) something like…

  1. Low (flat): period = 5, gain = 0
  2. Medium: period = 5, gain = 1
  3. High: period = 10, gain = 1

In addition to the demo `roslaunch wave_gazebo wave_wamv.launch ` for testing the buoy models, I would recommend taking a look at this demo: `roslaunch wave_gazebo ocean_world_buoys.launch`

If you look in the comments for [PR 114](#!/osrf/vrx/pull-requests/114/wave-visual-physics-refactor/diff) you can see how I used this, along with a model  generation script, to evaluate the change in computational resources required.  I think it would be good to do a few test cases, comparing the current default with this branch, to make sure that we have similar computation requirements.

In addition to the demo roslaunch wave_gazebo wave_wamv.launch for testing the buoy models, I would recommend taking a look at this demo: roslaunch wave_gazebo ocean_world_buoys.launch

If you look in the comments for PR 114 you can see how I used this, along with a model generation script, to evaluate the change in computational resources required. I think it would be good to do a few test cases, comparing the current default with this branch, to make sure that we have similar computation requirements.

content.raw:
I have addressed your style comments. I think it will be a good idea to allow using the buoyancy plugin without the wave\_model param. If the `wave_model` is specified we pull that information, otherwise we treat it like a flat surface. That would allow people to use this plugin without the wave model.

In that case, we can keep the buoyancy\_demo as a flat surface, and close #123 without merging. And I can work with wave\_wamv and ocean\_world\_buoys to test buoyancy with waves.
content.html:
I have addressed your style comments. I think it will be a good idea to allow using the buoyancy plugin without the wave_model param. If the wave_model is specified we pull that information, otherwise we treat it like a flat surface. That would allow people to use this plugin without the wave model.

In that case, we can keep the buoyancy_demo as a flat surface, and close #123 without merging. And I can work with wave_wamv and ocean_world_buoys to test buoyancy with waves.

content.raw:
I was able to run the demos and it looks really good.  

Have you been able to do an evaluation of computational cost as described above?  The current default branch should scale to ~100 instances of the buoyancy plugin.  It would be good to make sure that we can get similar performance with this modification - especially with models that use the cube and cylinder geometries.  

Once we put that to rest it is good to go on my end.

content.raw: We typically avoid throwing exceptions if we can recover. My suggestion is make this function to return a boolean value and decide accordingly afterwards. We normally show the error with `gzerr` and probably do not connect the `OnUpdate()` function if something went wrong.
content.html: We typically avoid throwing exceptions if we can recover. My suggestion is make this function to return a boolean value and decide accordingly afterwards. We normally show the error with gzerr and probably do not connect the OnUpdate() function if something went wrong.

content.html: I catch the exceptions and use gzwarn to display them out in load function

content.raw: I’m not familiar with the math behind this PR but I wonder if there’s a way to create a look up table to make it faster. Maybe we can consider some of the parameters that are important here \(the submerged volume, link velocities, etc.\) and precompute some results at the beginning of the plugin. Just an idea but feel free to ignore if it doesn’t make any sense.
content.html: I’m not familiar with the math behind this PR but I wonder if there’s a way to create a look up table to make it faster. Maybe we can consider some of the parameters that are important here (the submerged volume, link velocities, etc.) and precompute some results at the beginning of the plugin. Just an idea but feel free to ignore if it doesn’t make any sense.

content.raw:
I did a couple of quick tests and verified that the cylinder geometry does have an adverse effect on computational needs.  I also verified that running the test with 100 of the spherical buoys \(that use the sphere buoyancy geometry\) is much more efficient - back to RTF of 1.0.

I would recommend that we use a spherical geometry within the buoyancy plugin for our buoys - the surmark models and the colored totems.   I believe this will provide an imperceptible difference in fidelity for the case of the buoys without the computational cost.  

We’ll reserve use of the other geometries \(box and cylinder\) for situations where capturing the higher fidelity physical interactions is warranted.
content.html:
I did a couple of quick tests and verified that the cylinder geometry does have an adverse effect on computational needs. I also verified that running the test with 100 of the spherical buoys (that use the sphere buoyancy geometry) is much more efficient - back to RTF of 1.0.

I would recommend that we use a spherical geometry within the buoyancy plugin for our buoys - the surmark models and the colored totems. I believe this will provide an imperceptible difference in fidelity for the case of the buoys without the computational cost.

We’ll reserve use of the other geometries (box and cylinder) for situations where capturing the higher fidelity physical interactions is warranted.

content.html: Use `this->polyhedron` for member variables. We don't follow the _ convention.

content.raw:
Looking at using spherical geometry for VRX object buoyancy.  This appears to address the computational issues.  My testing shows that running with 100 objects still has RTF of 1.0 and frame rate of ~60.  Scaling up to 1000 objects drops the RTF to 0.11, which is consistent with the implementation in the current default.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/3618776803-image.png)
Will update PR shortly.
content.html:
Looking at using spherical geometry for VRX object buoyancy. This appears to address the computational issues. My testing shows that running with 100 objects still has RTF of 1.0 and frame rate of ~60. Scaling up to 1000 objects drops the RTF to 0.11, which is consistent with the implementation in the current default.

Will update PR shortly.

content.raw:
In [83e31e2](#!/osrf/vrx/commits/83e31e260079edbb4ed99e5691e72714d7c5bd30) converted buoyancy geometry for buoys to spheres.

Here is the demos I use:

1. Generate 100 surmark buoys

```
cd ~/vrx_ws/src/vrx/vrx_gazebo/scripts 
./generate_avoid_obstacles_buoys --L 500 --a3 0 --a5 0 --a7 0 --surmark46104 100 | tee ~/vrx_ws/src/vrx/vrx_gazebo/models/robotx_2018_qualifying_avoid_obstacles_buoys/model.sdf | tee ~/vrx_nosync_ws/src/vrx/vrx_gazebo/models/robotx_2018_qualifying_avoid_obstacles_buoys/model.sdf 
```

Run

```
 roslaunch wave_gazebo ocean_world_buoys.launch
```

This runs at RTF 0.99 for me \(frame rate ~60\).

2\. Alternatively generate N=15 of our 7 buoys/totems for 105 buoyancy objects

```
cd ~/vrx_ws/src/vrx/vrx_gazebo/scripts 
./generate_avoid_obstacles_buoys --L 500 --a3 0 --a5 0 --a7 0 --surmark46104 0 --N 15 | tee ~/vrx_ws/src/vrx/vrx_gazebo/models/robotx_2018_qualifying_avoid_obstacles_buoys/model.sdf | tee ~/vrx_nosync_ws/src/vrx/vrx_gazebo/models/robotx_2018_qualifying_avoid_obstacles_buoys/model.sdf 
```

This runs at RTF ~0.6

The culprit seems to be that the totem makers we use, which use the surmark46104 with addition of a “cover” visual and a fixed joint.  If I run a test with 100 black totems the RTF falls to ~0.55 or so.  Seems to suggest that adding 100 joints is pretty costly.  In the future, to save some cycles,  we could consider generating a dedicated mesh for the colored totems to avoid the added cover and joint.

Otherwise I think this is good for review.
content.html:
In 83e31e2 converted buoyancy geometry for buoys to spheres.

Here is the demos I use:

  1. Generate 100 surmark buoys
cd ~/vrx_ws/src/vrx/vrx_gazebo/scripts 
./generate_avoid_obstacles_buoys --L 500 --a3 0 --a5 0 --a7 0 --surmark46104 100 | tee ~/vrx_ws/src/vrx/vrx_gazebo/models/robotx_2018_qualifying_avoid_obstacles_buoys/model.sdf | tee ~/vrx_nosync_ws/src/vrx/vrx_gazebo/models/robotx_2018_qualifying_avoid_obstacles_buoys/model.sdf

Run

 roslaunch wave_gazebo ocean_world_buoys.launch

This runs at RTF 0.99 for me (frame rate ~60).

2. Alternatively generate N=15 of our 7 buoys/totems for 105 buoyancy objects

cd ~/vrx_ws/src/vrx/vrx_gazebo/scripts 
./generate_avoid_obstacles_buoys --L 500 --a3 0 --a5 0 --a7 0 --surmark46104 0 --N 15 | tee ~/vrx_ws/src/vrx/vrx_gazebo/models/robotx_2018_qualifying_avoid_obstacles_buoys/model.sdf | tee ~/vrx_nosync_ws/src/vrx/vrx_gazebo/models/robotx_2018_qualifying_avoid_obstacles_buoys/model.sdf

This runs at RTF ~0.6

The culprit seems to be that the totem makers we use, which use the surmark46104 with addition of a “cover” visual and a fixed joint. If I run a test with 100 black totems the RTF falls to ~0.55 or so. Seems to suggest that adding 100 joints is pretty costly. In the future, to save some cycles, we could consider generating a dedicated mesh for the colored totems to avoid the added cover and joint.

Otherwise I think this is good for review.
